reviewText: Does it break new ground? Does it innovate and excite? No on both counts. But as a physics exercise, Blarp is fantastic at demonstrating what VR, and more importantly motion controlled VR, can do.\n\nThe game is basic, almost painfully so. A psychadelic eyeball called a Blarp" is floating around in a box with you. You can 'attract' it by pulling the trigger of the Vive Bagel Blaster associated with your right hand
date: and the Blarp will attempt to make sweet
recommended: sweet love to your remote. When you stop pulling the trigger
hoursPlayed: the Blarp continues on its last path and velocity
voteText: whether or not your remote is still there. Also of note is that Blarps can not turn on a dime -- more accurately
helpfulPercent: they can maybe turn on a manhole cover. What this means is that you bull-and-cape it into running into a target floating in the box with you. Upon hitting the target
votesTotal: and now BOTH of those Blarps independently try to track down your Bagel Blaster when you pull the trigger. As you fling these helpless eyeballs into more and more targets
commentsCount: attempting to destroy the interloper (your remote) in their midst. You keep going until you "get Blarped" (to use the in-game verbiage)
column16: i.e. a Blarp runs into your remote.\n\nThere are no complex mechanics or systems to learn
column17: just an intrinsic understanding of momentum and spatial awareness. Yet despite the simplicity
column18: the game achieves its goal quite readily -- you realize that there is literally no way to play this game outside of VR. Without the depth perception
column19: you won't be able to determine how far away the Blarps are from your remote
column20: and by extent you'll end up striking out. Without motion controls
column21: you wouldn't be able to 'swing' the Blarps from target to target (although I will readily admit that a PS Move could easily do just this
column22: the only benefit of the Bagel Blasters of the Vive is being able to carefully sneak your way past a Blarp cloud as you gather them up for the next target.)\n\nAs a game
column24: it's lacking. But as a $3 demonstrator of VR technology? Yeah
column26: I think it does the job."
column30: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is like all of my 90s hologram stickers, come to life. Despite buying over $100 worth of VR titles over the weekend to play on my VIVE, the one I keep thinking about the most is Blarp. The sound design is fantastic, and the graphics are so trippy yet on point with a sense that I'm actually in the mentioned hologram space. If you own a VIVE, own this game. Now.

reviewText: Hands down one of the most magical experiences I've had on the Vive. The feeling of swinging the balls around the room is simply amazing.\n\nThe game requires a lot of patience in the later portions of a run, making it frustrating to lose to a simple mistake, and hard to come back to because of this. If the game had some sort of checkpoint system or Start playing at level 15
recommended: ..." system in place it would have a lot more replayability.\n\nRegardless
voteText: this game is a must buy."

reviewText:
If you have a vive, just stop reading this and buy this game.

reviewText: Simple, cheap, but one of my favorite games I've played so far.  HIGHLY recommend checking it out.  Tons of fun, and very unique.

reviewText: This game is AMAZING in VR. Only played a little bit on my Vive and it is a mini game type thing but the physics, colors, gameplay are all incredible. Really well made for VR as simple as an idea it is, feels very complex and feels satisfying every time you hit another ball. Highly reccommend to anyone who just got a headset as it is super cheap and super fun, better than some of the $20 games I've paid for so far.

reviewText: This is one of those games that looks a bit crap when watching video, but the sense of presence is incredible once playing.  A bit claustrophobic at first, everything is very intimate and up close.  Then, as you get further in, the space becomes huge and it's just so hard to describe how it feels.  Very addictive and a great show-piece for VR.  PICK THIS UP!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: One of the most unique and surreal VR games I've ever played. You spin these things above your head like a stretchy lasso and try to toss them at randomized targets. If they hit your hand you lose. Simple as that. Super trippy visuals and sound. A must play if you like weird single mechanic games.

reviewText: I would say this is my Vive sleeper" hit. I did not expect much
date: but it is truly SO much fun in VR! The graphics look strange on a monitor
recommended: but inside the Vive they look so awesome
hoursPlayed: really feels like you're in that grid room. I also love how the floor was done. The gameplay is simple but a lot of fun
voteText: if you have a Vive this is a must buy!"

reviewText: This game is the perfect mix of super trippy and ultra zen, and I love it.  One thing I'd like to see added is some more dynamic backgrounds, I love the peek into another world you get in the eyeball trails, I just wish that as you blarped more and more the world around you would shift and grow to be more and more psychedelic.

This game is the perfect mix of super trippy and ultra zen, and I love it.  One thing I'd like to see added is some more dynamic backgrounds, I love the peek into another world you get in the eyeball trails, I just wish that as you blarped more and more the world around you would shift and grow to be more and more psychedelic.

No other game has made me smash my controllers into my desk and walls as much as this one. I love it.

Be advised: At first you will resist the blarp. Then you will become the blarp. And you, being the blarp, will yourself will be blarped.

Pros: Blarp.

Cons: BLAAAAAARP

reviewText: This game is like snake in 3D space, best $3 I've spent.\n\nThis game did not look interesting to me at a glance, but I'm glad I tried it - you play with physics objects in a cube, you launch these little blarp things at a target and each time you hit it your space increases and you have to control another little blarp. It's easy at first but as you collect a few you're beginning to realize how difficult it is to keep them all doing what you want... when things get crazy, use your shield!

reviewText:
A very unique game at an excellent price.

reviewText: Woh. The world around you melts away, and all there is is Blarp.  Nothing else matters.  Your wife, your kids, your place of dwelling - you will forget they exist.  It's just you, and Blarp.  And that's all you need.  You'll want to sit in your cube of Blarp and Blarp non-stop.  If anyone walks in on you while Blarping, you won't know, because you will be Blarp.\n\nBlarp blarp blarp blarp blarp, blarp blarp - blarp blarp!  Blarp blarp blarp blarp blarp blarp blarp?  Blarp blarp.   Blarp blarp blarp blarp blarp blarp blarp blarp blarp blarp.

reviewText: Blarp is wonderful!  A truly innovative game that's incredibly beautiful and extremely fun. Like a psychedelic, 3-dimensional, zero gravity, billiards/croquet game from the future, Blarp is both a surprising mesmerizing art work, and an engaging original game. It's a fantastic example of the astounding potential for truly new forms of entertainment in Virtual Reality. Blarp uses a fundamentally new game mechanic that is so simple and effective, you'll wonder why you've never seen it.  It's because it's truly native to VR and simply wasn't possible before. If you've got a Vive, you owe it to yourself to get Blarped!
AMAZING! This is so trippy! It costs almost nothing and is one of the best Vive title. Thank you for developping such a little gem. You have to try to understand, but WOW!
Such a simple concept yet so much fun. Anyone can hop right in and play with no learning curve.
Wonderful demostration of slinging physics. It has inspired me in my own development efforts.
great vr game to play solo!
$3 roomscale-VR game where you swing trippy-colored balls around.\n\nMore fun than dropping acid.
For the cheap price, it's great. Simple mechanics, but trippy visuals and room scale immersion makes the experience pretty amazing.\n\nA lot of fun, even if it lacks long term depth.

Unless I'm missing something there is very little to this game.  That being said, I really felt a sense of delight as I controlled the movements of these cute, yet unemotional eyeballs flying around me.  The game mechanic works really well and it's a great concept that I'd like to see taken further by the author.

At first I felt like I was trip'n balls, but eventually I accepted this new reality! blarp!

In all honesty though, for what it's priced at, blarp is an excellent and fun VR game that really is unique in it's artistic style and sound design.
It's seems so simple that it's easy to get immersed and lose you self in blarp.

A game I would definitely suggest VR adopters give a go.
A must have for every Vive user.  The game is easily $10 worth of fun.
AMAZING! This is so trippy! It costs almost nothing and is one of the best Vive title. Thank you for developping such a little gem. You have to try to understand, but WOW!

This is a very simple game, but it uses a mechanic that would be impossible without motion controls. (I have played a few 2D games with somewhat similar ideas, but it really is a different and fresh experience in VR where you are part of the world and have to aim and dodge.)\n\nIf you get this without expecting it to be more than it is I can almost guarantee that you will enjoy the time you spend with it. While I'm playing I can't stop smiling, and to me it has definitely been worth the small purchase price.

from someone who yo-yos a lot, this is soooo cooool. It's so much fun!!! I've only played it sitting down and it's still great, can't wait to try it in roomscale. i didn't expect much and I only bought it because it's so cheap, but now that I've played it, I'd probably pay $10-$20 for it.\n\nalso, and maybe this is just me, but I feel like this is the beginnings of a waterbending simulator

Only played this for a bit, but wow!  This is very cool.  I definitly recommend for any Vive User.

Essentially it takes your play space and adds a virtual wall to it that allows these orbs to bounce off of.  You spin them around with your controller and try to avoid getting hit by them while adding more on.

Kinda like the game Snake but 3d and a lot more fun!

Very much worth picking up for its trippy, slower paced, strategic gameplay. Great demonstration of how to use limited space to make the player traverse the available area and work out the best shots. Arcadey goodness and does not put a timer in place to make you feel rushed. One of the better Vive experiences and totally worth the price. Hoping for increased variety of levels and challenges in the future.

Fun game and can't argue at the price. I found the controller and sheild models kind of weird but I guess it fits with the theme. Very cool being able to control the floating eyes and move around them, really shows off the 3D capabilities of the HMD.

Unless I'm missing something there is very little to this game.  That being said, I really felt a sense of delight as I controlled the movements of these cute, yet unemotional eyeballs flying around me.  The game mechanic works really well and it's a great concept that I'd like to see taken further by the author.

Despite constantly seeing this game recommended - it didnt look appealing.  I decided to give it a shot due to the low cost and was blown away.  This game is a must own.  The sense of place is incredible and the overall design is great.  I see myself coming back time and time again.
It may not be the best game on the Vive but it's certainly one of the most interesting and best value experiences. Definitely worth the money!

Kinda cool. Kinda different. A little weird. A good way to waste some time and well worth the low asking price :)\n\nAnd a game that could kinda exist in 2D with a mouse and monitor... but could not have existed in 3D up until now.

This is a no brainer for $3.  Seriously. It looks so simple but it's such a neat thing.  I really can't explain why I love dinking around in here for a couple minutes in between games but it's just a neat thing to have.\n\nI haven't played long at all but it's just a neat idea and it just feels" so awesome.  Great controls
date: subtle but powerful effects in the room and yeah..  Totally recommend this as a neat toy to dink around with."

I don't even know what to say about this game. Trippy as heck. For some reason it's fun. Buy it, I guess?

One of the better Vive experiences and totally worth the price. Hoping for increased variety of levels and challenges in the future.

This was not what I expected.  For some reason I thought this was going to be similar to Modbox.  This game is a great example of the thrill you get when entering a new medium... I had no idea what to expect and I was pleasantly suprised.\n\nI enjoy playing BLARP! but I think it needs local high score lists like Space Pirate Trainer and the ability to mute the music so that you can play your own.  If it had these two options it would be ideal.

At first I felt like I was trip'n balls, but eventually I accepted this new reality! blarp!

In all honesty though, for what it's priced at, blarp is an excellent and fun VR game that really is unique in it's artistic style and sound design.

A game I would definitely suggest VR adopters give a go.
Price is right to recommend it. I don't see myself coming back to it much, however it is unique and interesting. Very trippy visuals and sounds.

from someone who yo-yos a lot, this is soooo cooool. It's so much fun!!! I've only played it sitting down and it's still great, can't wait to try it in roomscale. i didn't expect much and I only bought it because it's so cheap, but now that I've played it, I'd probably pay $10-$20 for it.\n\nalso, and maybe this is just me, but I feel like this is the beginnings of a waterbending simulator
There's not much to this game. But unlike many of the early VR titles, this one is asking a fair price. I plan to play it more when I get a chance.

I didn't expect much when I bought Blarp. After all, quite a few VR-games" which costs three or five times more are just glorified demos. Blarp doesn't fall into that category though. It is indeed a simple casual game
date: but it is a highly entertaining one. It is neither scary nor violent and it relies heavily on fluid movements and precision on the part of the player
recommended: making it perfect for all ages
hoursPlayed:
especially as the learning curve is extremely low : if you ever swung a shopping bag you'll know how to control your flock.
As seems to be the norm for VR games : don't let the screenshots fool you. The game looks MUCH better when you are in it than what the flat pictures can convey.

If you have a Vive and at this (perfectly chosen) price

reviewText: It's really surprisingly fun. I don't expect to get a lot of hours out of Blarp! Maybe another 2 myself (trying to beat my high score, as that's all there is to do) and possibly another 2 demoing it to people. I'm totally okay with that. For the price I could either buy large Snickers bar or I could spend 2 hours in a gooey, dark cage flinging eyeballs that cut shreds into a dimension of hypercolor.
For $3 you can't go wrong with Blarp.  I'd consider it thoroughly in the wow
date: look what VR can do!" category... but it is really fun to sling those things around
recommended: especially in the teens and mid twenties.  Up into the thirties
hoursPlayed: the blarp swarm seems to be pretty unmanageable (mainly because of the extreme size/speed differences that build up)
voteText: but by that point you've already had a great time and a long turn
helpfulPercent: so it's time for someone else to play anyway :P"

reviewText: Wonderful demostration of slinging physics. It has inspired me in my own development efforts.

Interesting game, feels like the developer experimenting with vr physics games.\n\nYou are basically swinging balls around trying to hit a target which becomes a new ball when you hit it. the progression reminds me of snake.
$3 roomscale-VR game where you swing trippy-colored balls around.\n\nMore fun than dropping acid.

The future is here! Despite having nearly every Vive title out there, this one seems to have grabbed my attention more then anything else! We need more innovative ideas like these! Please add force feedback to simulate tension!!!!
wow.  absolutely beautiful.  tricky at first, but then you start to learn how to control the orbs using the full analog range of the trigger, and it becomes something special!\n\nawesome.
Simple, but quite fun and good value given the low price.
The more surreal the experience the better, and for the price point and the simple, yet fun roomscale controls, I cannot find a fault with Blarp.

I came close to passing this game up. The videos don't look that compelling, and the screenshots less so, but the reviews and the $3 price convinced me.

This is possibly the best VR game I've played yet.

The premise and gameplay is simple, and yet incredibly fun. This game takes a lot of patience when you get dozens of BLARPS! floating around, and can be incredibly frustrating when you're pushing for one more and and a tiny BLARP! sneaks up behind you and game over!

While this game might not be for everyone, at the $3 price I think it's absolutely worth taking a moment to check it out.

edit: speeling
It's a fun inexpensive colorful trippy game.
